input_doc:
I knew in advance how small the rooms were, and for the price I paid, the location of this hotel was hard to beat.
I had an unexpected guest join me, and found that a double room really only *just* accomodated the two of us, but when you are in San Francisco, your hotel room should just be a place to sleep! It filled this purpose very comfortably.
The TV worked, the shared bathroom was clean and we never had to wait to use either the restroom or shower. The eco-friendly approach and vision of the Mosser is a definite plus too.
Our only gripes would be the noisy kitchen staff at the restaurant below, the slooooooow elevator (the stairs are fine as an alternative though) and that the desk staff couldn't tell us the best way to get to the Haight District. Bring your own map, and ask at the information center around the corner to avoid confusion.
Overall, an excellent option for those who want to see the city, but not stay in a hostel. I'll stay there again next visit.

We stayed at Casulo because the price was right, but we got much more than we expected. The beds are sooo comfortable. We have a memory foam mattress at home and we usually can't wait to get back to our bed, we could move in to this petite suite. We had planned to get up early but the bed was so comfortable we slept until 9. The two headed shower room is totally unique to any hotel. We are planning to use some design ideas from this hotel in our next renovation. The complimentary breakfast was totally a bonus, the design of the lobby clean, modern and fresh. If you like modern you'll love Casulo, we do.

input_doc: While planning our first trip to San Francisco I came upon this hotel rated well by other reveiws. The location was central, with a wonderful veiw. The price was right and the hotel was clean!!! We will return to San Francisco and enjoy another great stay at The Chancellor Hotel.

The W Hotel is a tired, tired property. The lobby is full of purple, curvy "hip" couches that are stained from the hipsters "petting" them, not to mention the holes in them with stuffing coming out. Rooms are no better than a Holiday Inn Express, but with chartreuse accents and a couple of Budha statues stashed about. Although a devoted Starwood patron, we had never stayed in a W before. The only reason we stayed int he W was because the St. Regis was fully booked. I do not know if all the W Hotels are like this. But I would definitely avoid the San Francisco W. Was "price" the saving grace? "Heck No." Room, room service (a dessert that was simply, bad) and parking puts you at about $500/night. Waaayyyy better alternatives....

input_doc:
My boyfriend and i stayed at this hotel for 5 nights and had no problems at all. Its true the rooms are quite small but it was perfect for us. They were cleaned every day and the staff were fine. There was some work going on in the hotel but it didnt bother us. I would definitely go back again and really do not have anything bad to say about the staff or the hotel. If you do decide to stay here at the Astor there is a lovely sandwich place on the corner (take a left as you come out the hotel) and the tube station is also round the corner which is a great as its not far to go. I dont really understand the other reviews maybe we were just lucky but it was perfect for us. I hope you have a good a time that i did - cant wait to go back again!!!

input_doc: I stayed here one night for a mini college reunion, the staff were soooo nice. One of the three rooms we booked wasnt ready at 4pm when we checked in so they took off $100 the rate per room, and even threw in a free drink at the bar while we waited. The beds were super cushy with down comforters. The room size was average for a big city, but the bathroom was big I thought. Also we could walk to almost anything, North End, Fanueil Hall. Had an awesome breakfast at Kinsale an Irish restaurant nearby as well. Would definately stay here again next visit.

I would be surprised if this hotel doesn't increase their rates in the very near future. For someone who wants to stay in Times Square, this is a great location. For someone who likes a nice hotel, good value but very nice rooms, this is a great hotel. I was a little leery when my friend booked this hotel because I usually stay in midtown at a "nicer" hotel. When we arrived, there is a beautiful lobby that overlooks all the lights with a great bar. The rooms are far nicer than the W which is just down the street, and at a far better rate. The rooms are modern and newly renovated. The steam shower is incredible!!! The hotel is clean and the staff as friendly as you would expect for Manhattan. I would definitely recommend this hotel if they are looking for a medium range hotel which is truly 4 star quality.

input_doc: I was pleasantly surprised at the overall experiece I had with this hotel. Traveling across the country can have its drawbacks. I however, was very pleased with the fact that I could experience a piece of home so far away. The breakfast was enjoyable (everything was fresh) and the room was very clean and comfortable. I appreciated the courtesy and flexabilty shown by the all of the staff. From the hotel operator, to the front desk staff, I was treated with respect and excellent customer service. All in all, I would definately recommend this hotel to anyone traveling to Pasadena. input_doc: I stayed at the Kimberly Hotel for business and was very impressed with the rooms and level of service from the staff. I stay at hotels often so I would consider myself a bit of a hotel snob however The Kimberly Hotel exceed all of my expectations. When I checked in, they did not have any rooms ready, however the Front Office Manager Charles took great care of me storing my bags while I headed to my meetings. When I checked into my room later I was so surprised by the size of the rooms, WOW! This hotel is the epitome of what a boutique hotel should be; monogramed towels, wonderful shower heads, plush bedding, robs and slippers and the list goes on! I typically stay at the W hotel when visiting NYC however from now on the Kimberly Hotel will get all of my business!!!

input_doc:
Okay, we are a family of five - three kids under 12!!! To my delight we were given a room with a view of the river. It was spacious, comfortable, and the pool and fitness area were spectacular. My kids loved the pool and it stayed open late and opened early, keeping them busy!!! 
I would definately recommend this hotel to any family looking for a great value for the $$$ and for the luxury accomodations that come with it. It is centrally located to the highway, close to central and south Philly - a short distance either way. We were able to enjoy Chinatown and "Little Italy" in minutes which was nice. And waking up to that view is beautiful!! 
We have stayed in Philadelphia before and will definately be back for seconds at the Hyatt!!!

input_doc:
Since I havent been to NYC for 15 years and my wife has never been there at all, wanted to make sure we were in a central location to be able to walk to most sights and areas, and the Park Central is perfectly situated with that in mind (stayed for a long weekend). The hotel is a huge beast but it's got everything you'd need to make a stay worthwhile...we had a clean quiet room with a comfy bed and a bathtub to soak away the foot aches after walking for 8 hours a day. It was easy to check in and out, and the in-house concierges (there's several of them) were patient and provided helpful suggestions without any attitude. Buy some bagels and have breakfast in central park (2 minute walk) to start your day and have a great time!!! The price was fantastic (through Expedia-got 300$ savings booking flight and hotel together) and the Park 
Central was a perfect place to crash after our adventures.

input_doc: Great Hotel in good location. On checking young lady at reception decided to take a phone call and leave us standing there with no instruction for 5 mins. Her colleague eventually took over and handed us our room keys.......okay ! what room where we what floor were we on, no communication, so first impressions not good. The room was very clean and modern abit on the small side, but overlooking the courtyard was better than overlooking a road. Wine tasting is served between 5pm-6pm which is great after a long day sight seeing. On check out again, we had a rude receptionist, as you can be charged to use your room safe or ask for it to be waivered. input_doc:
I can't say enough about this hotel!!! The location is great because you have easy access to everything San Francisco, without having to deal with the high "touristy" areas every night. There are street cars that run right next to hotel which can bring you directly to either Fisherman's Wharf, or the Mission District. The cable cars start 1 block away. The Ferry Building is directly across the street, which you can easily get to Sausalito and Vallejo (which is what we did to get to Napa). The hotel staff was extremely courteous and ALWAYS helpful. The conceirges seemed to go out of their way to get even the simplest request for information quickly and accurately. The rooms were spotless and very comfortable (I would highly recommend spending the extra $$$ for the Superior Waterfront View because the view of the Bay and the Bay Bridge is incredible any time of the day, during any weather). I have never written an online recommendation before, but I am so glad to do so now!!!

input_doc:
I stayed at the Westin St. Francis for 4 nights on business. It got off to a bad start. I arrived near midnight from the airport and the hotel did not have my reservation in the system. Luckily, I had the email confirmation to show them. The gentleman helping me was able to get me a standard room at the nightly rate that I had reserved. It took a little bit of time to get things straightened out and at that late hour, all I really wanted was to get check-in quickly over with. I gave them my Platinum SPG number. Unfortunately, the hotel was not able to recognize my Platinum status for some reason. The reason one stays with Starwood is the excellent treatment for Platinum members and if that's missing, then one might as well stay at any other business hotel in the area like the Grand Hyatt or the JW Marriott. I don't blame the Westin St. Francis particularly; it's very likely a problem with the central reservation system through www.starwoodhotels.com.
My standard room was 2 double beds in the new tower because I wanted some more space than the classic rooms in the old tower. The room was around 300 sq ft. The room decor is typical corporate blandness, but it's new and modernized The bathroom was a very good size with a bathtub that had double showerheads. (But I thought the toilet was out of a Motel 6 as it did not fit in at all with the higher class Westin image. It seemed cheap and cheaply installed.) The bed was comfortable and up to the Heavenly bed standard. The walls seemed to do the job to block noise from adjacent rooms. I did hear noise from the hallways but there's really nothing one can do about it.
I did not get to use the WiFi. Also I did not get to use the health/fitness center.
There are many elevators and the wait for them was fairly short. The hallways are well lit and very clean. The lobby is grand and certainly very attractive, but I noticed there are not many seating areas for guests who need to wait around or meet someone. There's a coffee shop directly opposite reception that has seating but it would seem you need purchase their food. The location in Union Square is excellent for tourists and those traveling for fun. This hotel wasn't my first choice since I needed to walk over to the financial district for work (about 15 mins brisk pace). All in all, I cannot say with confidence that I would stay here again due to the bad start.

input_doc:
Siamo stati in questo Hotel dal 22/06 al 29/06 due adulti e un bambino di 12 anni.
La posizione e' davvero ottima ( ed e' quella a mio avviso che giustifica la scelta di questo albergo per altro molto pulito) con un costo rispetto alla media di Manhattan piuttosto conveniente.
Peccato per il rumore insopportabile(11 piano) dovuto a finestre senza un minimo di isolamento e al cantiere nel palazzo di fronte, con operai al lavoro a partire dalle 5,30.
Altra pecca per un albergo a Manhattan l'assenza del WI - FI gratuito.
Cortesia del personale : non un segno particolarmente distintivo dell'Hotel.
Mi raccomando assicuratevi che i lavori al palazzo di fronte siano finiti!!!!!!

input_doc: We stayed at La Quinta Manhattan on Nov/2011 with a family group. We had confirmed reservations for 3 rooms. They pre-approved 4 rooms (one more than my reservation) in my credit card but, when we arrived, only 2 rooms were available. 2 couples had to share the same room for the first night. They told us that the guest that was supposed to leave decided to stay, so, they couldn`t honnour our confirmed reservation!!! The next day they mooved the couples to theirs own rooms. The rooms were on the back side, no view, but very comfortable and clean. Everything was fine for the rest of our stay, nothing else to complain.

input_doc:
went to stay for one night with my hubby, shower was beautiful..one of those waterfall ones. but if you're looking for a hotel name while driving up madison avenue, which is stressful enough as it is, dont bother as there is no hotel name out front..just the street number. its on purpose, so it feels more like home. as a visitor, i prefer to have the name on front so when i stumble out of a bicycle rickshaw at 3 am drunk i know where i am. 
the bed was super comfy, i wanted to take it home with me. we had a 2 room suite, it was ok..lots of comfy pillows. 
the free breakfast was nice as it ended at noon, not at 10 am like other hotels.....we never make it to those as who wants to get out of bed that early for a bagel?? it was the basics, creeal, fruit, pastrys...they were pretty bland though.
but seriously, when you cant figure out how to work the lights in the bathroom when youre sober, its too difficult. too confusing...just give me a switch!! 
all in all it was a ok place, the staff was friendly.

input_doc:
We have stayed at this hotel a few times in the past few years for a conference. This time, the front desk staff attitude was slightly better than the previous years, but don't expect them to be super welcoming. They are cold, and do the bare minimum of what they need to do. The rooms are ok, nothing too fancy, and relatively clean. For $500+/night, you get the room and nothing else. We got one newspaper for the four nights we stayed. There is no WiFi in the rooms. They charge you extra $15 per day for WiFi. Seriously? I guess Hilton hasn't realized it is almost 2012 and WiFi is really available for free everywhere else. You can access WiFi in the lobby free of charge, but there is no place to sit in the lobby. There is a starbucks in the hotel, but unlike other starbucks don't offer WiFi (I guess the hotel doesn't let them)!!!
Oh, and the HHonners...really, you get nothing for it unless you are a diamond member. 
Hotel location is great. But, if it wasn't for the conference, I would stay somewhere else.

input_doc:
I arrived at our room at around 10pm after being at the Carlsbad Econolodge and Leogoland for two days. What a downgrade in rooms. Since we were going to Sea World I wanted a closer hotel which this hotel is close to Sea World. The property is clean and the guests all appeared to be family's like us on vacation. The property is non smoking in the rooms so guests stand outside and smoke which in my opinion is worse for our non smoking family. The hotel did not appear to have any breakfast other than the free complimentary one that was in a large room off the lobby. The items for my stay was an apple, orange, bananna, coffee, Milk, Cereal, and danish/muffins. Nothing worth writing home about. 
Now for the problems with the room. The blanket under the comforter had hairs on it. Gross!!!
We stripped the beds and just used the whte sheet. The beds are doubles. When we arrived the air conditioner and refrigerator were turned off. The room was hot and smelled stale. The air conditioners had two speeds high/low. Medium was broke. The refrigerator was the small dorm room style which took a day to cool. Then after I was gone for the day at Sea World the cleaning person turned my air conditoner off after I purposely left it on so I could come back to a cool room after a long hot day. The bathtub water spout was also set to bath a person who would be no taller than 5'. I would guess that if your over 6'4 you would not even be able to stand in the shower as my head was almost touching the ceiling in the tub. No a great showering experience. I only paid about $70 with tax per night if you pay more than this I would recommend staying somewhere else. Old Town which is across the street has some nice shops.

Just stayed at the Hotel Adagio for 3 nights. We're upgraded to a Junior-suite on check in... We were therefore quite excited as we thought that this would be a really nice room....wrong !! The rooms, furniture, linen and bathrooms are very old. Spent a little bit of time trying to work out how old...and settled on about 20 years +. We were advised that the hot water would be cut that afternoon due to refurbishment going on, but that it would be all systems go by 6pm. I rang down to reception 3 times to no avail. As it was, we finally got hot water at 10.30pm. Like a previous reviewer, we booked the hotel months in advance...in fact 4 months, but we were never advised of the refurbishment.
The bar and snacks are expensive...but I guess that that's how it is in most city hotels. 
Staff were efficient and polite which make up somewhat for the decor.
I would say, ok for maybe one night, and if it was cheap....but otherwise get ready to step back 20 years.......

input_doc:
I stayed at Jacksonville CP Riverfront Dec. 31 to Jan 3. The hotel desk staff were wonderfully friendly people and I commend the hotel for that. In addition, the beds were amazing - not like any other hotel I have stayed in. 
That said, the room (which did have a great view over the river) was TINY. The bathroom vanity was so small there was not enough room for makeup bags for two female travelers. Yes, the room was old and outdated but I could have lived with that. Yes, it was during the Gator Bowl, it was New Years Eve and people were partying in the halls a bit. I could have lived with that too.
What KILLED IT for me was the SLAMMING DOORS all night long. I could even have lived with THAT had it not been for previous reviews stating that such was a problem. Like other past guests, I too was assured by management the problem would be addressed. My best guess is that the doors are still a-slammin' while CP Jacksonville Riverfront rakes in $369/nt. during special events AND charges $10.00 per day for parking to boot!!! (Manager told me in an email that probably shouldn't have been done, given the room rate, but I didn't see a refund on my credit card statement!). 
Oh, and where were those "signature sleep amenties" mentioned on the website?
Never again - Omni here I come.

input_doc: The hotel is very conveniently located for business in the financial district and some of its design features are impressive. However, good design does not automatically mean good quality in interior execution. Given that the place is open since January 2010, my -very nicely proportioned- room looked pretty shabby already. The cheap wood flooring was severly scratched and worn, wear and tear on furniture, crafting pretty bad. Staff / service VERY mixed experience. The guy checking us in was very nice and helpful, so were the staff at the restaurant for breakfast; most other "hosts", i.e. receptionists, were pretty arrogant in communication and service responses. I have no clue where that attitude comes from and why it is being toterated, but makes you think why these people took a carreer choice in the hospitality industry.... Lets summarize the rest: beautiful black bahroom, very low water pressure, so the rainshower looks like more fun that it turns out to be; housekeeping so,so; free good quality drinks in the minibar; nice Geneva sound system. Would I recommend it: yes, for the next year - after that the guest room fittings should look somewhat worn down - plus dont expect genuinely interested service by front office / concierge. If you can live with that - go for it.

input_doc:
I choose this hotel because it was advertised as "100%" Smokefree. Yes,all the rooms are non-smoking, but the doorway of your room maybe a designate"smoke area" by where the ashtray/trash bins are placed. To make things worse, at 10 pm.,I heard talking, only to find a smoker leaning on my door with a cell phone in hand, dragging on a cigarette, and talking very loud to a friend in YAYAland. AGHHHH.

As a Dallasite-my wife&I were excited for a little stay-cation at the new Omni in downtown. Honestly, we were thoroughly underwhelmed. Yes-the view is nice. Yes-the Sports bar is sweet. Yes-rooms are nice....but not as nice as The W or The Magnolia. And after spending $150 in bar&$200+ on a room.....they still charge $18 for self-park....not valet....self-park. Left a bad taste in my mouth. I found it to be low rent. In addition, once you are in the hotel, it's not super-safw to walk anywhere. Whereas at other downtown spots-you can.....here I would cab it.

input_doc:
We stayed one night. Room and all was fine. 
I asked if I could pay cash at desk because I hate hotel holds on MY money. They said it was cheaper to use the card because cash would be almost $300 anyway (for an 85.00 stay???) Marriott adds $20-$25 if you pay cash or stay on points. 
So after check out I see a $229 and $50 hold! After looking at our receipt, the total bill with valet was $119.00. What sense does this make. I figured Monday it would fall off and actual charges would be applied. Nope. Called my bank Tues. and they said the hotel could call them and they'd drop it. Called the hotel. They claimed they would, but I knew they wouldn't. Gave me the speech about how many days a hold could be on....really? And YOU'D be ok if this was your checking acct? We were 5 days gone at this point. 
Long story short. Actual charges were applied late in the week. Largest hold came off Thusday (6 days after check out) and the $50 by Friday. Ridiculous. 
I will NEVER stay with this lot of thieves again. A cash payment should be for the room price and a small incidental fee. And holding for almost $300 on an $85 room? Peace Westin. Back to Marriott. They treat us well and don't bust our account "because they can".

input_doc: great location, awesome staff, 5 star restuarant....would love to give it a 5 star rating overall but found the room though beautiful very noisy due to lack of acoustical finishings in rooms and hallways. Don"t take rooms across from the elevators as late night club revelers and early morning sightseers may keep you up as happened not only to us but to guests that we spoke to throughout our weekend stay. Also our shower leaked eveytime it was used making the washroom rather awkard to function in. One last thing the television didn't connect to movie system as was supposed to and although service was prompt on looking into these issues for us neither the shower nor the tv was fixed during our 3 day stay.

input_doc: I was a little disappointed as to the outside of the building when we arrived. The plants on the porch were not very appealing and seemed to cheapen the decor. Also the windows of the rooms were dirty, could be due to the proximity to the street. Also the walkways were not clean but the rugs to our room could have used some updating. lus trying to find out room was a little confusing by the signs outside. We were told by the hotel staff to be sure not to leave any valuables in the car and be sure it is locked. While it is close to the T and the wait is not long at all the ride into town was over 30 mintues. The eating area where the breakfast is available was very small and didn't allow many to eat at a time. The food was the usual nothing out of the ordinary when you have to help yourself. I was diappointed with the room. I beleive there was suppposed to be a picture above the bed but there was just a nail and a paint missing from the wall. The bathroom must have been recently updated but wasn't finished professionally. A little disappointing.

When you walk into your room, I think your first response will be...seriously, this is HUGE! For one person, I thought I had been misplaced. The room was a suite. I think it would've been better if I wasn't paranoid and actually stayed with someone else. Being alone in the huge room styled in the olden days was ..to sum it up in one word..creepy. Three of my colleagues and I were down at the bar discussing the rooms. We are three ladies, traveling alone and each in our own rooms. We were all talking about how creepy the rooms are and how we each may be sleeping with the lights and tv on. I heard noises at times....it all sounded like people running up and down the halls either above me or outside of my door. There were never any voices, just running footsteps. This happened a few times, and it never lasted very long. There are mirrors above the beds that serve no purpose. It's not like you can do your makeup in the mirrors. They are old, and they make the things in the room look strange. There is also a normal mirror in the bathroom and then on both sides, there are two mirrors with candle looking lights in front of it. These are the lights for the bathroom. The mirrors are not something you can see yourself in. It's just really strange. If you like the old feel, this may be the place for you. On the up side, the staff is extremely nice and very willing to help!!! The maid service, the front desk, the concierge, the valet, doormen, restaurant staff, all EXCELLENT! If I hadn't been alone, I may have given this another notch. Location of hotel--it's in the business district, so if you're near here on the weekend...most things are closed. Be very careful is you're walking alone..lots of homeless people and some are straight up crazy! There is a police station and a jail in walking distance too. If you're walking towards the grassy knoll, which is about four blocks away, be careful if you go alone.

input_doc:
Coopers Square has one advantage: It has a monopolistic location of being 'new', in walking distance to NYU-Washington Square , Greenwich Village, West Village, much of Soho and being upper-class... but for the $400 price-tag the rooms and their bathrooms are ridiculously small, with minor irritating things like the cheapest thinnest toilette paper and small towels where they clearly saved on fabric-softeners to add insult to injury. On my 8 or so rides in tiny elevators I squeezed in with room-service's carts 3 times: This would be a great hotel if the prices were half of what they charge....

input_doc:
Lo mejor del hotel es la ubicacin porque tienes muchas cosas cerca, el empire state, times square y un largo etc.
Ser que en Espaa estamos acostumbrados a otro tipo de hotel por este precio, pero a mi me pareci supercaro para tener una habitacin en la cual la moqueta huele a pies (la primera compra que hicimos en NYC fue un ambientador), un aire acondicionado que no te deja dormir del ruido que hace y una ducha con una presin bajisima, vamos que tardas 40 minutos en ducharte...
Nosotros teniamos una habitacin superior con bao, pero de superior nada... 
Por otro lado aconsejaros que intenteis conocer a John en la recepcin porque es encantador y os da todo tipo de trucos para divertirte sin gastar mucho dinero. El resto de los empleados no son tan agradables...
Cuando llegamos al hotel nos cobraron 700 USD de mas (totalmente inesperados) porque segun recuerdo tienes que pagar el 14,5% mas de lo que te cuesta la reserva (nosotros la hicimos por clickbed.com) y 3,5USD por persona y noche por dormir en Manhattan... vamos una pasta..
Ah! las sabanas y las toallas no las cambian... si lo pides te cobran 5 dolares cada vez...
Lo mejor del hotel la terracita que hay!!! ahi se puede fumar, llevarte la comida, etc... es un rincn muy agradable...

input_doc: I traveled to Boston for 1 night on business and I was looking to save a few bucks versus brand name hotles in the downtown area. The Bulfinch turned out to be centrally located in the area I needed to be near and its price was at least $50 less than other nearby hotels. The hotel was clean but the room was very small with barely any closet space - the King bed basically filled the room-the lighting was terrible and I couldn't really see well enough to read unless I went into the bathroom which was pretty decent....I believe that next time, I'll pay a liitle more and stay at Brand Name 4 star hotel.

input_doc: This hotel MAY be a 3 1/2 star establishment??? It is clean. It appears that it would be nice for convention/conference needs. It also seems to be the Indy Hotwire "special". Although, I hear later this year they are converting it to a student facility. For what it's worth, and while it is still available, I would spend some extra money and find a hotel that is truly in the downtown Indy area. This place is NOT really downtown. The rooms were nice. However, there are NO extras offered at all here. No lobby coffee, no continental breakfast, no free parking (at $18-this makes the Hotwire deal not so great). This was not a bad experience, I would just go somewhere else next time. (And not book on Hotwire, just in case.)

input_doc:
Actually, i had just left the Hotel Carter (ABYSSMAL!) and when we pulled up to this hotel, i actually breathed a sigh of relief! what an amazing location! the bellhops were jonny-on-the-spot with our bags and we were whisked inside. i'm here as part of a production crew, so they handled all the niceties with the front desk. i was placed in a room on a very high floor, and i found it very comfortable, tho it did have stained and dingy carpets. the lobby is beautiful with several restaurants therein, and the location is AMAZING to see whatever you want in times square, and madison square garden is RIGHT across the street! 
the cleaning staff were there when i needed them, and i even requested batteries for my remote and a gentleman came right up to give me some. there was NO internet connection available in the room i was using, however there was web tv... mine didn't work tho. no matter, prices were exorbitant.
but not as exorbitant as the fone bill. i made several unconnected calls from my room and ended up with a bill of over 300$! so i went down to the front desk and with the help of a nice lady, she erased the charges that were not connected. i still ended up with about 100$ when i connected on about 5 calls - which i suppose is not really the hotels fault, but a bigger problem involving more telecommuncations companies. i was still grateful for her assistance.
tho we did have to change rooms a few times, we stayed about 4 or 5 nights. i had a grand time at this place! it felt very safe, and if i was ever bored, then i just went for a walk. tv worked excellently, tho there did seem to be lots of kids running up and down the halls....
could use some updating, but all in all, a good place to get some sleep.

I chose this facility due to reviews made on Tripadvisor. Overall my room was clean and everything worked. I will say with I-17 freeway being so close I was able to count the cars at night, especially trucks. The room I was assigned is toward the rear of the property so things can't be better closer toward the freeway. I attempted to make a toll free call from my room two hours after arriving and could not dial out. Searching for assistance I called the front desk and was told to give it a "little time" and they would have the problem solved. A half hour went by with better results so I called the front desk again. I was told someone was going to come to my room to remedy the issue. No representative came to my room. I made four calls in three hours. After three hours passed they quit answering my calls so I called their main number from my cell phone. I asked to speak with a supervisor and was told he had just left for the day. The person answering, Johnny, asked if he could assist me so I told him who I was and was in room ---. He said please hold. I did for a few minutes. Johnny came back on the line and said "try it now". I did and it worked. Whatever Johnny did he could have done in the previous hours. It was a very frustrating experience. Last night with rain falling in Phoenix I was awakened many times with the loud sound of a lot of rain pouring on something metal. This morning I went outside to find out what kept me awake most of the night. On the back of the building there are no gutters nor overhang from the roof. Rain from the roof was falling straight down and falling on a metal security light. That light was opposite the headboard. There might as well not even been a wall between the light and the headboard as it was loud enough to keep anyone awake all night. One other issue was upon driving up to my room after being gone all day I found a male employee attempting to enter my room. I asked what he wanted and he said there was a water leak in my room. After examining the kitchen and bath there was not a water leak anywhere. Not sure what his intentions were beyond that I was puzzled as to his true agenda. I am thankful I came back to my room when I did. There are many places to stay in Phoenix. My suggestion is to try somewhere else.

input_doc:
We stayed here for three nights. Brittany at the front desk was nice to let my dad check in even though i wasn't with him.(room was in my name)...I arrived later.
The room was dirty. Had to ask the front desk for new sheets...I made the beds over myself. When I asked for more pillowcases was told they had run out! (Explains why the beds were dirty to begin with). Like stated in a few previous post....in three days there, never once saw a vacuum cleaner. i even asked for a garbage bag from one of the house keepers and her cart didn't even have a place for a vacuum! I don't like people entering my hotel room, so we never had housekeeping enter after we checked in. Bring slippers to wear, or don't take your shoes off. 
Breakfast was ok. Not a full breakfast, just a expanded continental. No eggs/protein. Only carbs: Waffles, biscuits and gravy, bagels, muffins, fruit and yogurt. Juice and coffee. Hardly any seating. All mornings just got a plate and went back upstairs.
Shuttle Service: Saw the lines...waited 30 min then took a cab. Didn't want to spend more of my vacation waiting for a shuttle. If you're up to it, Independence Hall is about a 15-20min walk up a slight hill. 
Parking: Expensive. Street parking is free after 10pm and until 8am. Several blocks away(south..turn right from the driveway.. on Columbus) there is a lot for $10/overnight; $8 during the day....park there and call for the shuttle. 
Check out: CHECK YOUR BILL!!!! They charged me for three days of parking when I only used one, and charged me for a microwave and fridge that never arrived!
Would I stay again...yes, but I'd check my bed first again and ask them to explain the charges before signing (that's how I found the over charges). This is a nice place if you're someone who can roll with the punches. The beds are comfortable, and the breakfast does give you a nice "snack" to start your day. They just need to learn how to manage their high volume of visitors.

input_doc: My daughter and I stayed at the MK on Aug. 11-13. We arrived before 3pm and our room was available immediately. The decor and condition of the rooms is dated with lots and wear and tear but no obvious dirt, odor, and I'm happy to say, no bedbugs!. I had booked this hotel in April and as I rely heavily on Tripadvisor information to make many travel choices was worried because the latest reviews for this hotel have been bad, very bad. I went so far as to book another hotel and cancelled it at the last minute b/c the location of the MK appeared to be great. So, I hoped for the best and did make a good choice in terms of location. I liked the size of the hotel...........it has a cozy feel and nice bar. The staff members were friendly and helpful. Now the big question I always ask myself when trying to evaluate a hotel.....would I stay there again? I wouldn't reply with a resounding, NO. This was my first trip to Chicago and I don't consider the stay a mistake. But I saw other hotels in prime locations that I would like to try.

input_doc:
A long overnight stop on the way back to the UK after a family adventure holiday in Peru, dictated some luxury. The Parker Meridien provided some but perhaps not enough. It performs very well up to a point but.... The room rate was good 225 for a suite for four (though that didn't include breakfast for our 2 children which was expensive). They allowed us to checkin early (but forgot that we pre-booked a late check-out) The swimming pool was nice (but the attendants were very protective of long-term hotel residents and strictly limited access) The room was excellent, the best hotel bed/linen/duvet we've ever had (but no-one came to makeup the sofa bed, we did it ourselves, but then found the sheets had been used by previous residents) The bathroom was sleek and worked well (but was full of small black flies) Breakfast was NY -rich and huge, (but the service was a little overbearing and children didn't like it much) The mirrored reception area looks as though it should hide lots of mysteries, (but it doesn't - the whole thing is very clinical) The reception and door staff were first class (the room staff weren't) 
It's rather like that large class of good restaurants which do two excellent course but a lacklustre third.
I think I'll look for somewhere with a bit more character next time.

input_doc:
Not your father's business hotel, and maybe not yours either. The lobby becomes a disco with a DJ at night. Coming home late from a show, expect to wander through crowds of drunk people gyrating to loud music. Say hello to the big bouncer stationed by the elevators to keep these people confined to the lobby.
Welcome to your room. Strangely shaped, you say? Yes, why *didn't* they take another 15 sq ft or so off the ample bedroom to make a bathroom that isn't so small you can't open the door all the way without it banging into the sink?
How do you like the decor? What shall we call it? Hmmm, maybe 1980's Playboy Magazine Chic? The broken lampshade and the towel rack that falls off the wall whenever touched do spoil the mood a little. But don't worry: I'm sure the maid is used to mopping up the water that is just naturally going to wind up on the bathroom floor from the shower stall that has neither a door or a curtain.
That being said, the location of the hotel is excellent. When you're feeling down about your room, you can walk across the street in one direction to the Marriott to see what an affordable hotel looks like or across Lexington to the Waldorf Astoria to see what a really nice hotel looks like.
With any luck, you won't have to wait until 6:30 pm to get into a room because the Starwood Preferred Guest in your room is exercising his privilege of "late check out". Thanks, guys, for the compensatory free bar vouchers; I don't drink.
I was in a two-day meeting in the hotel, and I will say that the meeting rooms are superb. I've probably never been in a nicer hotel meeting space, and the catering for the meeting was also excellent.
Everyone I dealt with at the hotel was professional, cordial and eager to serve.

input_doc:
We find it hard to believe that this is a 4.5 star property. We often stay at 5 stars and due to pricing, figured we could get better bang for the buck staying at the Omni, which was about $100 - $150 less than the 5 star properties. Unfortunately, we were wrong. Here's a quick summary:
The Good
-location - very close to the shops of Michigan Ave and lots of excellent restaurants in the area (bars, pizza joints, Italian, you name it)
-friendly service - people working here were genuinely pleasant and friendly
The Bad
-had difficulty finding an outlet to charge my phone in the bedroom area of the suite - when it serves as my alarm, need it close by
-TV in bedroom area was an old box....the nice TV was in the suite
-cleaning of room wasn't that great from day to day
-dated decor
-rooms are VERY dark
The Ugly
-iron kept leaking water
-white drapes had brownish red stains
-parking is $54 a day....wow...unreal!

input_doc:
I have been to New York several times so am not writing this as a novice visitor. We stayed at the London for 7 nights and our friends for 5 nights. We were on the 10th floor and our friends on the 30th. Our suite was better in terms of size, they had a great view. We agreed on the following: (i) overall, we have stayed in better hotels in New York for little or no more money (ii) the service at the London is patchy - the conscierge team was generally very good but the reception and restaurant people were "functional" - one thing that really hacked me off was when ckecking-out we were neither asked whether we had enjoyed our stay nor thanked for our custom (iii) the lighting and the decor throughout the hotel is gloomy, but especially so in the suites (almost impossible to read a book in the sitting room after dark) (iv) the cleaning staff did a good job but housekeeping generally could have been much improved. In addition, in our room the sliding door to the bathroom hardly fitted the frame and came off its runner with annoying regularity. On the plus side the hotel is very clean and the location excellent - between Central Park and Times Square and between 6th and 7th so handy for MOMA, Met Museum, shops, Lincoln Centre etc. 
We will not be rushing back to the London NY. There is no denying that to have a suite in New York is something of a luxury but as you don't go to NYC to spend time in a hotel I would have preferred a great room rather than an "okay" suite. I think I will go back to the Sofitel next time - smaller rooms than the London but great beds and bathrooms and, at the end of the day, those are the only two things that you really need in New York. Alternatively, whilst the Omni Berkshire was a little tired the last time I stayed (in 2008) the room size was amazing and is equally well located.

input_doc: Booked it for $USD 415/night on the hotel website with an AAA discount. 2 interior hallways down from the Hynes Convention Centre. Free wifi on 1st and 2nd floors. Free access to onsite huge gym with lots of weight machines and treadmills, and massive pool and cozy hot tub. 7 minute run to Charles River. Lots of eateries in adjacent area (Newbury Street, Prudential Mall, etc.). Grocery store (Shaw's) directly across. Closest T stop (Prudential, Green Line) is within connected mall. Great view from 25th floor. Old, dusty and a bit dingy in decor. Small rooms, especially once crib and fridge placed for our baby. Ridiculously tiny bathrooms. Quick elevators. Uninterested frontdesk staff in response to complaints re: significant delay in arrival of requested crib to room.

input_doc: I recently, today,booked on priceline and "voil" I got the Hilton Washington -Dupont circle for August 11th to 13th. We are two adults and two children, so I wanted to make sure we got 2 beds so I called the hotel. With a voice that sounded like a mother berating a child, this person handling reservations told me: "this is why we tell customers not to book on priceline...." Wait a minute: doesn't the hotel have to give priceline the okay to book their rooms? She explained to me that because of how I booked the rooms they couldn't guarantee what I was going to get. WHAT? Aren't all your rooms good quality? I asked her to transfer me to the manager and she said I would have to redial and hit the appropriate number to get him.This is not a good beginning. I did get the manager, after hanging up and redialing, and he quickly laid my stress to rest and said we were getting a two bed, smokeless room. My fingers are crossed that the room and amenities will shine.

Yo recomendara este hotel a gente joven y no claustrofbica ya que los cuartos son muuuy chicos, el hotel en general es obscuro y el lobby los fines de semana por las noches es super ruidoso por el super popular bar y nightclub. El servicio por lo general es descorts y toma mucho tiempo en registrarse. El hotel tiene un diseo muy bonito y moderno. La terraza en el piso 15 es muy tranquila y bonita con buena vista de la ciudad. El restaurant (que parece la cafetera de Harry Potter) es caro y nada especial.
Como yo no llevaba mucho equipaje y slo pagu $150 usd/noche me pareci muy bien.
Nota: el servicio de internet lo cobran aparte.

input_doc:
Stayed here in late June 2012. Lovely room, sparsley but tastefully furnished. Beds and pillows were comfortable. A luxury elegant bathroom. The hotel foyer was vast and impersonal. We paid extra for a Bay View Room but the view we got was completely marred by a large black factory chimney and some aluminium venting on the building between the hotel and the waterfront. The so called infinity pool had been photographed so skilfully that the chimney and other premises could not be seen. There are no coffee making facilties in the room and so we had to have room service, this cost $20 for a pot of coffee for two (including room service charge and tip) Coffee was available for a limited period in the morning from the lobby. Valet Parking (no choice it's valet or nothing) was $39 per night. We chose this hotel from the web site and we feel that the photo was so misleading and resulted in us leaving the hotel a day earlier than planned. Despite the quality of the room and furnishings we consider that the hotel was extremely poor value for money. To be fair we completer a customer survey on line from the room and as a result the manager did give us a $50 per night refund which we received when we arrived home.
Pike pub is across the street and whilst noisy it is a convenient place to eat. Pike Market is a block away and worth a visit. Access to the waterfront is down a few flights of steps so beware if you find steps difficult. It is also worth considering that Seattle is very hilly. It also rains a lot!!!

input_doc:
I'm convinced that there is a black hole in the lobby sucking all the light away... it's just so dark! Seriously it needs about a hundred new light bulbs, but don't let that turn you off....
That said, the rooms are very comfortable although the bathrooms a quite small. You can see how it is a very old hotel, but to be fair they have done a good job modernising it. 
I would think that it's a great hotel for tourists as it's very centrally located. It's ok for business once you don't mind all the kids running around.... but to be fair the internet is better than some other more business focused Boston hotels (I got the internet access for free, so I'm not sure if it's expensive)

input_doc:
I stayed here the weekend of 2/11-2/13 and the hotel looks really nice when you pull up and go into the lobby. That's when you find out you are going to pay $14/day to park your car. Seriously? I can stay at the intercontinental, Westin, or Omni and not have to pay to park my car. Then you get to your room. Very clean no issues there other then it looks like the last time it was updated was 1980. Nothing like watching TV on an old box TV when the shows that are being shown are in 16:9 widescreen format. That was nice...... Then you pay $13/day for internet access and it didn't work. I could not get online the help desk couldn't even get me online. Noone would give me a refund for this. The staff at the front desk is super nice i think the issue was just out of their hands. 
Getting to the hotel presents its issues also if you don't have a GPS and you aren't from the area good luck to you. I lived in Dallas for 2 years and had a hard time getting to the hotel for the first time. All in all if i had to recommend a hotel to a friend that wanted to stay in this area i would send them somewhere else. In the end this is not a 4 star hotel. If the rooms were updated it would be 4 star easily but its very dated and doesn't meet 4 star expectations.

input_doc: I think the title says it all, but it's nice to find a hotel with waffles, eggs, coffee, juice, creals and breads included for free. The added bonus was that there was even nice wine and beer from a tap also for free during the weekday evenings, but check before going. They also had a mini buffett with a nice simple salad and some other food. I wished they had a vegetarian option other than the meat option for the buffet, but can't complain since it was free. The location is easy and close to the beach if you have a car. If not, it's too far to walk. But, there's a free shuttle that can drop you at the beach area in Del Mar and then pick you up when you're ready. The walls are a bit thin so you can somewhat hear your neighbors. The rooms are nicely decorated, but I'd wish they'd lose the silk plants. They are just dust collectors no matter how clean a room is. Couldn't they just get a simple real potted plant that does not require a lot of water? The flat screen TV was nice, and the bed had a poor quality mattress. I think you just need to make sure you really get a suite, as we thought we'd have one, and to our suprise, it was just a couch on the other side of the room opposite the bed! We were traveling with a small baby and wanted that extra room to be able to not disturb her when she was sleeping. I hear from others that the rooms do differ and some are really suite like with a separation between rooms, so make sure you ask for what you want if they have it available. I'd stay here again. Front desk was friendly and helpful. Next door is a SPA at the Hilton Garden Inn and I got a nice hair cut. It's a bit pretentious there with all the Spa rules though..they have a SPA Etiquette list on the back of the pamplet that made me almost not go there. I ended up going anyway to the spa for a haircut with my daughter and it was empty. Not sure why all the rules, but per the rules, they don't want kids (i.e ones that can make noise). Luckily they let me bring my kid who was good, but who wants to go to a place where you're not really welcome with your little one? I would have spent a heck of a lot more money there if they were more welcoming with in their pamplet. And especially since it was empty, don't think my kid would have disturbed anyone except the other staff if I had stayed to get a massage and facial!!!

input_doc: Let me start by saying, this is my first ever boutique hotel experience. My lack of knowledge in boutique hotels could have alot to do with my review. Front desk and staff were exceptional. The cheese and cracker tray delivered to you room was a great touch. Parking, well... There is none unless you valet for 24 dollars a day or park you car on the street (if you can find one). No store, or shop, only options is getting things out of your mini bar, 4 dollars for a can soda. This hotel has a night club attached to the pool, so if your going to the hotel for relaxation, not such a great idea. At night, it is a local club with girls in there short skirts and 7 inch heels prancing aroung the bar and pool area. No hot tub. If your thinking of staying with family, not the hotel, if your going to party.... Perfect. Housekeeping was great the first 2 days, then last 2, you couldn't even tell they were there. The rooms all in all aren't much better than a Marriott or holiday inn, now they do have a sofa, and I stayed in a regular rooms. We did ask to check out the magnificent 7 hotels, are were shown about 4 of those, and they were super nice. All in all, it was an okay experience for a 20 something non party girl and her mom, but next time I'm in Dallas, I won't stay at zaza.

input_doc: Scenic beauty as it is right on Charles river and located closeby to Harvard and also to downtown. Opt for a suite as a standard room would be smallerby american standards. You get a large size cookie as welcome on check in. Nice !. The Hotels' complimentary shuttle service to Harvard Square and Copley Place is very impressive as it runs religiously on schedule, and on time. input_doc: El Hotel basicamente es para ir a dormir, sus habitaciones son pequeas, pero comodas, tienen lo necesario y estan limpias, los desayunos que te incluyen, son muy basicos, pan, huevos, cereal, dos frutas, leche o yoghurt, cafe y ya.. yo dira que estan bien, siempre y cuando te puedas aguantar con eso hasta en la tarde, el personal es amable y tratan de resolverte si hay algn problema, aunque no te pelan mucho, solo cuando sales y por ltimo la ubicacin, es muy buena, esta a unas cuantas cuadras del metro y muy cerca de times square, te puedes mover sin problemas a cualquier parte, lo nico que la cuadra donde esta, es un poco fea, pero solo la calle, todo lo demas bien, yo lo recomendara si lo que te interesa es salir todo el da y llegar solo a dormir, el precio es bastante bueno, dentro de su categora el mejor precio, por que todos son muy caros!!!!

input_doc: If you are looking for a good location with a bed, bathroom, clean towels and reasonable price this is the place to stay. Great location as you are steps away from times square, central park and the tourist buses all stop just across the road from the hotel entrance. The park cafe on the ground floor is good for breakfast and dinner with attentive staff. The staff in the small shop on the ground floor are extremely helpful and can organise, trips, limos, show tickets and give you great advice about anything you may want to do whilst in the city. Ok its not the most luxuirious hotel in the world but the rooms are clean and if you dont pay 5 star prices then what do you really expect for the money!!! Get reall all those moaners on this site you only get what you pay for!!!!!!!!!!!!

input_doc: I guess I should have known better I might have had myself hyped for more. I grew up in Austin and have always wanted to stay here... For our one year ann. I total splurged and booked a room in the Historic part of the hotel. Paid $100 extra for the romance package which was 5 covered strawberries, champagne, turn down service and breakfast in the morning... First the entrance is gorgeous. No question and the girl at the desk was kind and wonderful we were running behind so we had to hurry or miss our dinner reservations. She heard us talking about it and offered to call the resturant and let them know we were on our way but might be a few minutes late. It was a save. The front desk girl was above and beyond. I did feel shorted once we got into our room which I felt was way too small and had a view of a brick wall. We were also told we could not have our dinner companions come up to our room to get ready to go out when we asked that they be sent up when they arrived. While waiting out front of the hotel for their taxi at the end of the evening we were told they couldn't wait there or in the lobby. We were not drunk or really drinking thru out the evening 2 glasses of wine. I felt that was rude. If we had been tipsey it would have been understandable. The breakfast was to die for!!!!! But all in all I felt it was way over priced for what we got... Oh and I found out later it was a 10 dollar bottle of champane if you go to specs... Such an excensive hotel and you still have to pay for parking...

input_doc: We just returned from 3 days at L'Enfant Plaza Hotel in Washinton DC. This hotel is in a great location. It was clean, the staff were very friendly and the concierge was extremely helpful. The Promenade mall in the lower level of the plaza and the metro station were very convenient. We were told that there are were no restaurants around, however, on our last night there, we ventured out for a walk and found 3 restaurants across the street by the marina. One was Sushi, one was chinese and one was a seafood buffet. It would have been a nice change from the restaurants in the hotel that were a bit pricey. Breakfast buffet was $16.00 an adult and the average entre on the dinner menu was $20.00. Take note that their dinner menu at this time of year is shortened, so not a lot of choice. There are a few places to eat in the promenade mall, some fast food, some cafeteria style food. It doesn't matter where you eat in Washington, it's expensive everywhere. Most of the museums etc....have cafes where you can grab a quick lunch. Our room was clean, but I think the hotel is a bit dated and is looking to do a full renovation this fall, so you may want to call them before you book. The pool was great, but would have nicer if it was open a little later than 8 p.m. If you want a hotel with a great location, this is it. I don't think you'll be disappointed. We would stay here again.

input_doc:
I wish I had read some of these other reviews before booking my 3-night stay here. The first night was the worst -- I had the room right across from the elevators (1201) and there were drunken people screaming in the hallways from basically 2 am to 4 am. Granted, it was a Saturday night, but I actually had a business meeting the next day and could have used the sleep. I called the front desk who told me they would send security, but that didn't do much (if they ever even came) and came very close to going all-New York on these jerks by opening by door and telling them to shut the (---- --). The next morning, when I complained again about the lack of sleep to the manager, I was given a coupon for a free breakfast. Given the lack of sleep, and the fact that I was actually there for business, I should have been given something a bit more valuable. I couldn't help but notice that several other people also complained about the noise that night.
I switched rooms for the next 2 nights and the noise wasn't as bad, though I could still hear the person next door sneeze, so the complaints about sound-proofing are spot on. 
It wasn't all bad: it is a cute hotel, the rooms were pretty spacious with nice features -- free (and reliable) WiFi is a must for me -- and the food in the restaurant was good and reasonably priced, especially compared with most other hotels. So if they could just fix the noise issue and perhaps group the bands of marauding drunken folks in one place away from everyone else, it would be a much better hotel.

input_doc: Let me temper this...I am not usually a luxury hotel visitor. But we had a sudden trip to San Francisco and I looked to tripadvisor for recommendations. It seemed a lot of properties in San Fran were expensive, so I figured "It's a special trip...let's blow the budget and stay in a luxury hotel", and the Omni is rated #3 so we booked it for 4 nights. The pros: it is a beautiful property, and the bed was so comfortable and the room was very quiet. They clearly have excellent soundproofing, and as my husband is sensitive to noise, this was great. The cons: I was a bit surprised that at a near-to-$300/night property, I had to pay 95 cents a minute for local calls, and that the "business center" was a $6 charge for 15 minutes of internet. The coffee machine in the room didn't work well, and after leaving a note for staff requesting regular coffee packs only instead of half decaf, we still got the half regular and half decaf allotment each day. Granted, I'm sure if we called the front desk we would have been accommodated, but again, at a luxury property, I had an expectation that they would note our preferences. And the only real "perks" were a bit of fruit and iced tea available in the lobby in the afternoon - ??? So, all in all, it was a great sleep, but paying close to $300/night for a bed with really no luxury perks left me a tad disappointed.

input_doc:
As many reviewers have noted this is a standard convention hotel that charges too much for the room and way too much for everything else ($12.95 a day for internet service--warning: wireless service is quite spotty and they cannot or will not do anything about this...including deduct the fee from your bill!). The rooms are fine and the beds are comfortable.
Was guaranteed a king-size bed, but when I got there it was not to be had. A nice girl at the desk took care of this and had me moved to the room I requested on my second day.
I guess it is still new and things are certainly glitchy. The showers have zero pressure, water so soft that you will feel soapy the entire time, and...this was my favorite....the water gets warm...never hot! There is a sign that says you may need to run the water for some time to get the right temperature, but if it gets anything warmer than warm it must take longer than ten minutes! (By the way, they place this sign next to another sign that says they won't clean towels unless you ask them to because they want to save water!)
The bar is fine with overpriced, but good drinks--the decor a modernism that reminds me of the UN Headquarters or mid-century Soviet. The gym is large and new, the lap pool looks great, but there is no sauna or hot tub.
I don't know--it is fine, not great...certainly not grand. Maybe in a year or so the place will be running smoother and the details will be worked out, but until then you might want to look elsewhere.

input_doc:
We reserved a King Superior room for 3 nights. When we checked in at 2pm, they said the King room we reserved was not available, and to come back in 1 hour.
At 3pm, they said all they have is a queen std. 
This room was soooo tiny, the size of my bedroom closet back home. Ok for s single, but way too small for 2 people.
3 other couples we were traveling with checked in later that day and all had issues with their rooms, A/C not working, room too small, etc.
After 24 hours of complaining, the manager finally was told by the bellhop to put us in a better room. At least the bellhop understands customer service. The manager didn't seem to care.
They moved us to a King suite. 
If I ever stay here again, I would only book that type of room.
Location was great, and they have a real nice bar area with a Jazz band.
I left my laptop power cord in my room when I checked out and after 3 phone calls, I finally gave up trying to get it back. They refused to send someone down to the room to look for it. They referred me back to the manager. like that was going to help..

input_doc:
Stayed here because of an early flight home. Check in was easy. We had paid for breakfast, but were leaving before 6am, when breakfast started... luckily when we pressed the issue we were given a voucher to contact room service for a continental breakfast, which we did. Room on 11th floor was lovely, clean and well kept, altho outside windows were pretty dirty. (But who cleans outside windows on the 11th floor?!!) 
View towards LA included flight path of planes landing - thrilling to watch as we were higher than them as they passed by, and yet triple glazing did a great job. Sleep number beds provided much entertainment!!!
We were so looking forward to having a drink in the bar at the top of the hotel, but when we took the lift up, it was closed. There seems to be construction going on, but there were no signs saying it was closed. Very disappointing.
We walked along to the LAX Marriott for dinner in the sports bar, as we found the grill in the Radisson a itttle expensive for us by the end of the holiday, but a farewell drink in the Radisson's lobby bar was very nice, good atmosphere.
Check out was quiet at 6am, but they tried to charge me for room service breakfast until I explained we'd had vouchers. 
As it's so close to LAX it seems to be the courtesy shuttle's final stop, meaning that the first shuttle was too full to take us to the airport. But because of the number of people waiting, the driver radioed ahead and within minutes had an empty bus pick us all up.

input_doc: We choose Hilton properties 99% of the time when traveling. The only time we have ever been disappointed to the point of using the Hampton 100% Satisfaction Guarantee was in San Diego. Beware - the train runs right behind the hotel!!! Not conducive to a good night's sleep! The Internet connection was iffy. The tub had been torn out and replaced with a shower, so no tub option. To top it off, we came in one night and had no hot water. We checked out the next morning and asked for our money back. They tried to get away with refunding half, but my husband simply pointed to the sign on the desk that said "100% Satisfaction Guarantee" and we got a full refund.

input_doc:
Stayed 4 nights in Nov 08 during election week. The first night we got stuck in a smoking room due to a huge youth convention and us arriving past 10pm to finally check in. I understand that all the other rooms may have been taken but felt disappointed that front desk didn't tell us during check-in to expect a room that was different than what we had reserved.
The next day our room was changed to a bright spacious quiet corner room, as requested in my reservation, with a view of the street just outside the hotel entrance. Nice sunny sitting area, functional granite kitchenette (bring your own pots and pans unless you're ok with rusty or scratched up ones), separate vanity area, and quality sheets were greatly appreciated. Our toddler had lots of space to play.
Internet worked fine. Just bring a cat 5.
Tried the in-house restaurant -- burger, steak, soup -- my most unfavorite meal of the trip. Service was so-so. Skip it and explore the numerous dining options all within walking distance.
Mustafa, the front desk staff person, is probably the most wonderful part of the hotel. He's friendly, helpful, and never rushed you to get to the person behind you. Thanks for making our stay a fabulous one, MUSTAFA!!!

input_doc: Got this hotel via hotwire so I got about a 40% discount from its publish rates. Not too bad but I might get a better deal with priceline. Having said that here are the pros and cons of the hotel. Pros- nice cozy hotel, close to fisherman's wharf about 10 mins. walk to Pier39. There's a safeway and walgreen just across the street from the hotel. concierge was helpful on giving instructions for which trip to take or which public transpo to take. free wifi at the lobby only. comfortable bed, decent aircon/heater service, with in-room safety box, complimentary starbucks coffee in room, rooms are cleaned everyday and serviced nicely. Cons- expensive parking, no free wifi on rooms, small clothes storage, relatively small bathroom, no in-room refs, no in-room utensils such as spoon, fork etc., our room was way at the end of the corridor near the emergency exit at one end of the building so it is such a long walk everyday we go in out of our room. A relatively old hotel that was just re-dress or renovated with some carpets, wallpaper, repaint etc. so you could see some of its age showing.... Never tried the fitness area so can't comment on that. With swimming pool but since weather was cold never bothered to check it out also. Having said that.... this hotel is quite good since most measure hotels based on sleeping comfort and location...

Location, location, location! Situated in the heart of Manhattan, close to Times square, all main theatres. Central Park within a short walking distance. Priced moderately for a downtown New York hotel. Amentities are modest, service is good. The interior is showing its age, needs renovation. Wi-fi Internet was very slow, and did not work at all on the first day of our stay. If you stay on upper floors, you would have to choose between their two old, tiny, and squeaky elevators which are often hard to catch and a very narrow and steep staircase. Families with children and older travelers, beware!!! Beds were not comfortable although we are not spoilt and fussy travelers. Would recommend this hotel only if there is no better alternative in the area. We had no other choice because all other hotels in this part of Manhattan had been booked by then.

input_doc:
I recently stayed in this Hotel a trip for my daughters 21st with my sister and her daughter. This hotel is location, location, location however, it is a hotel which needs some renovations. We had a couple of issues with the Hotel firstly they take 100 off your credit card even though you have paid in full??? Breakages I was told but had we of broken anything it would have been because it was about to break. Safe instructions incorrect had to get someone to help, light switch broken, cable coming out (leaving a hole in wall). We had to bring these to attention of the hotel as we didn't want to be charged for them. Towels/bathmaths weren't replaced (4 girls in a room) toiletries very scarse still using small soaps thrown out and being replaced the next day. Because of weight restrictions on planes I dont bring these type of items. Then the toilet got blocked last straw. I rang down and was told it would be a while but the Manageress Ruth was very apologetic and would have changed us had our daughters not been out at the time she also compensated us with breakfast for the rest of our stay. When I went to reception to get the vouchers the girl on reception (cann't remember her name) wasn't as nice same girl who checked us in (100 issue).
Service in the restaurant was very good.
Basic hotel in need of upgrading great location.

input_doc: It's not the most luxurious place I've been to and in most cities it'd be much cheaper, but this is a good base to explore most of the main sites of New York. Staff were helpful whenever we asked them anything. The room was clean, although there were a few holes in the walls and several sorts of wallpaper from different eras in the one room. No bedbugs! Wonderful old creaky lift, if you like old creaky lifts (which we did). One warning: the rooms at the front of the hotel can be even noisier than normal in New York due to the Mid Town Tunnel nearby. But then no one comes here for the quiet.....my 6 year old daughter loved the place; there's a great pizza restaurant a couple of doors down on the same street and a good diner round the corner.

input_doc:
The Hotel: As with most of SF there is limited space and although Ritz Carlton does a good job with the lobby and other areas, it just feels it needs a renovation. I may be biased beacuse I usually dont stay in SF and not used to the small size hotels. The service is typical Ritz and I say that in a good way. My one complaint would be the doormen didnt make me feel invited and seem to spend most of their time with someone who may give them a large tip. 
The Room: Small.....They do the best they can with the space they have but as mentioned before a renovation is in order and I fully understand the cost and logistics to keep the hotel open during renovation is a nightmare. We just returned from Rosewood Hotel Georgia in Vancouver and they also have limited space but Ritz should use them as an example. 
Fitness: No pool and there is a large area for yoga and stretching but again the same theme of being small with limited equipement. 
Spa: Didnt use it but the area always smells nice and the staff working the area was very nice. Tea and coffee is available near the spa.
Restaurant: We ate there twice for breakfast and it was very good. Our waiter on the first day was very nice and catered to our daughter and our friends kids very well. My wife had the buffett and she liked it but maybe a bit overpriced but the quality was definetely good. The kids french toast covered with cereal was a hit with the kids. 
The second day breakfst was a Tuesday and our waited looked like he was in training. Not as a fun an experience as the first( i wish I could remember his name to give him credit). 
Location: Good and correct from other reviews of being close to Chinatown and Union Square. Just a 5 min walk to either place. The trolley also around the corner from the hotel. Didnt have a car so cant comment on parking but Im sure it is very difficult.

input_doc:
Can't fault the location of this hotel, thought it was excellent.
Not so sure about the room.
We were on the second floor and in retrospect should have asked for a different one.
The street noise was a little bit troublesome but the main problem was the lethal step up to the toilet/ shower.
This was positively dangerous and the toilet/shower was miniscule. We are of average size and barely had room to fit in. Anyone who is slightly overweight would find it a tight squeeze.
Also the shower didn't have a curtain, so lots of possibilities of slipping over.
We also had the same problem as a previous reviewer in that our room wasn't serviced.
I suggest your cards are reworded. We were quite happy not to have our towels replaced but would have liked the beds remade and the tea/ coffee replaced.
The beds were very comfortable.
The staff were very friendly and the hotel was clean. it was just that step...................
Probably wouldn't stay here again but maybe in a better room.

input_doc:
Went down for an overnight shopping trip. 
Pro's: 
1) Very professional and friendly check in employees
2) Decent hot/cold breakfast as expected. 
3) You get a guest pass to 24Hour Fitness located across the street. Nice bonus if you are a work out freak. I unfortunately didn't bring my Nikes :(
Con's:
1) Really soft bed that squeeked...barely slept. 
2) The carpet felt dingy. Highly recommended that you wear your shoes while in suite.
3) Bathroom faucet and bar faucet have incredibly low water pressure.
4) Sketchy area. We were lucky to find street parking across the street in front of 24Hour Fitness. Felt better that the gym is open 24hours. I would have paid for valet parking otherwise = $28. 
5) Beware that this is not a quiet hotel. It's on a major street leading up to I-5. Lots of traffice in front of the hotel. 
6) Crappy TV signal. The Residence Inn Lake Union offered HD channels (for comparison). 
7) The bath curtain was cut short, I assume because the bottom was moldy and unsightly. It was so short that water from the shower created a mini-lake around the toilet. Not nice....

input_doc:
I'm very late in submitting this review. I stayed here during the weekend of the NYC Marathon in 2004 and hope to again in 2005. 
 The Good: Was perfectly located for all the things that I needed/wanted to do to get ready for the race. And other places i.e. a great pizza joint, small supermarket, 24 hour coffee shop, CVS, etc. were right around the corner. The staff members were attentive and very friendly. They had internet access available in a common area, and the gym wasn't all that awful looking either (didn't use it, though). The room was clean and the bed was so comfortable...heaven! And on Marathon Morning, the staff had complimentary water and power bars downstairs at the check in/out area. Nice touch! But really, LOCATION, LOCATION, LOCATION!!! That was key! I was really hurting the day after the race, and the staff was so nice in assisting me with my bags down the escalator.
 The Bad: Teeny-tiny television set, but then again, the room was very small, so a normal sized tv probably couldn't have fit in there. No small fridge, bath tub or coffee maker (all essentials for my pre- and post-race rituals). No dressers for clothes, small closet. For the most part, my clothes stayed in my suit cases. But hey, I got the room thru priceline, and at an awesome rate, so for NYC, you could do a LOT worse.
 The Ugly: Nothing....I loved the contemporary styling of the rooms and the hotel. My bathroom was spacious enough (although no tub...oh, how I needed a hot bath after the race, but that's ok). The club was opened until 3am or 4am, looked like a lot of fun (couldn't go...had to rest), and the noise stayed downstairs, which was great as it was critical that I got a good nite's sleep before the race.
 I've read other reviews pertaining to the dissatisfaction of some because of the room size, and yes, they are very tiny. But for me, the Hudson served it's purpose. It gave me a clean, quiet, COMFORTABLE place to sleep. I'd stay again in a heartbeat!

input_doc:
The hotel is a bit hard to get to  the front faces away from Colorado avenue, in fact you must turn right onto cherry creek drive then turn right into the hotel (if youre heading north on Colorado)
I like a clean, quiet, comfortable room, with some amenities nearby (restaurants, etc). this hotel fit everything except for a few items:
Number one  the bed was way too hard. It has a control to make it softer, but didnt seem to work. Unfortunately because the bed was so hard, I doubt I'll stay here again, which is unfortunate because the hotel does have several things that I did like.
Theres construction going on and its a must to have your car valet parked as theres no parking. This caused us some concern as we just had our jeep restored. We were assured that it would be parked in covered and secure parking, however when we were walking to Mikes camera, we could see our jeep sitting on the street (didnt sit well with us)
Theres a restaurant on-site, its not bad, has a limited menu, though. No lunch and room service is only from 5pm  10 pm. The morning breakfast buffet is outrageously priced ($12.95 per person). Didnt stop by to see if they had anything other than the buffet. 
There are a few places within walking distance, Panera Bread, a Cafe Rio Mexican Grill and a Garbanzo Mediterranean Grill. We didnt bother with anything other than the Panera Bread, because the menu at the other places just didnt seem right.
To get to the Panera Bread, however, you have to walk in the path of cars coming into the hotel. 
We did find a good Chinese restaurant that delivered. Golden Shanghai, www.goldenshanghai-denver.com

input_doc:
Our family stayed here for a night prior to the Flower Show. The hotel is very close to the Franklin Institute, Academy Of Natural Sciences and the Convention Center.
We requested early check-in and we received our room early as requested. The rooms are large with a fridge and microwave. The bathroom was avg to small. 
The room was cold upon check-in,so we turned up the heat to 80 degrees. After a few hours, the room temperature was only 67 degrees. I called the froont desk and they sent a person right up. 
He worked on the unit for about 20 minutes and we had heat, although the fan and unit was louder than in most hotels I had stayed. We already had our stuff unpacked, so we just lived with it.
The staff is very friendly and helpful. The manager's reception offers just about anything you could want as far as drinks. The bar tender was very fast and friendly...The only drawback was the food consisted of pretzels/chips/nuts....not even close to other Embassy suites we have stayed at in New York and Florida which had a selection of hot appetizers/frozen drinks.
We heard some construction noise from the on-going renovations, but nothing too bad.
Our cooked to order breakfast was in the TGI Fridays on the second floor. The usual hot foods and omelette station which we enjoyed. Again, not comparable to other ES I stayed but a nice meal. Our rate included tickets to the flower show.
Overall, my kids had a good time (11,11,13) as did my wife and I.
I would stay here again if we come back next year. A very good value for a clean, well located hotel. Nothing too fancy but a solid value for your money..
